pace-calculator.title: Running Pace Calculator - Free Race Pace Planner
pace-calculator.description: Calculate your running pace per kilometer or mile. Free online pace calculator for runners, joggers, and marathon training.

howItWorks.title: How the Running Pace Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your running pace (time per kilometer or mile) based on distance and total time. Knowing your pace helps you plan for races and train more effectively.

steps.name: Enter Distance
steps.text: Input the distance you covered in kilometers

steps.name: Enter Time
steps.text: Input total time (hours, minutes, seconds)

steps.name: Calculate Pace
steps.text: The tool calculates your pace per km/mile and speed

useCases.title: Race Planning
useCases.description: Determine starting pace and target pace for races

useCases.title: Speed Training
useCases.description: Set pace for interval training

useCases.title: Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor speed improvements over time

seoTips: 5:00 min/km pace is good for recreational runners
Start races slightly slower than your target pace
Train at different paces (easy, moderate, fast)
Monitor your training pace to avoid overtraining
commonMistakes: Starting too fast in races
Not accounting for elevation and weather in pace evaluation
Focusing on pace in every training run instead of easy running
Comparing your pace to more experienced runners

faqs.question: What's a good pace for beginners?
faqs.answer: 6:00-7:00 min/km is good for beginners - consistency matters most.

faqs.question: How do I improve my pace?
faqs.answer: Through regular training, interval workouts, and long slow runs.

faqs.question: Should I always run at the same pace?
faqs.answer: No, variety is important: 80% easy running and 20% speed training.

race-time-predictor.title: Race Time Predictor - Marathon and Run Time Prediction
race-time-predictor.description: Predict your race finish time based on your current performance. Free online tool for 5K, 10K, half, and full marathons.

howItWorks.title: How the Race Time Predictor Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool uses the scientific Riegel formula to predict your time at a new distance based on your performance at another distance. The formula accounts for the fact that pace slows as distance increases.

steps.name: Enter Previous Race
steps.text: Input the distance and time of a race you completed

steps.name: Set Target Distance
steps.text: Select the distance you want to predict

steps.name: View Prediction
steps.text: The tool calculates your predicted time and pace

useCases.title: Marathon Planning
useCases.description: Predict marathon time from 10K or half marathon performance

useCases.title: Goal Setting
useCases.description: Set realistic goals for upcoming races

useCases.title: Race Selection
useCases.description: Know if you're ready for a certain distance

seoTips: Use a recent race result (within 2-3 months)
Predictions are more accurate between similar distances
Distance-specific training improves actual results
Weather and course affect actual performance
commonMistakes: Using training run results instead of actual race results
Predicting marathon from only a 5K race
Ignoring the need for distance-specific training
Expecting major improvements without additional training

faqs.question: How accurate are predictions?
faqs.answer: Very accurate between similar distances, less accurate for marathon from 5K.

faqs.question: Which distance is best for prediction?
faqs.answer: Half marathon best predicts marathon, 10K best predicts half marathon.

faqs.question: Why is my actual performance different?
faqs.answer: Training, nutrition, weather, and race-day psychology all affect performance.

vo2-max-calculator.title: VO2 Max Calculator - Cardiorespiratory Fitness Tool
vo2-max-calculator.description: Calculate your maximum oxygen consumption (VO2 Max). Free online tool to measure cardiorespiratory endurance and fitness.

howItWorks.title: How the VO2 Max Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: VO2 Max ≈ 15.3 × (Max Heart Rate ÷ Resting Heart Rate)
howItWorks.explanation: VO2 Max is the maximum amount of oxygen your body can use during intense exercise. Measured in milliliters per kilogram per minute, it's the best indicator of cardiorespiratory fitness.

steps.name: Measure Resting HR
steps.text: Measure your pulse in the morning before getting out of bed

steps.name: Enter Data
steps.text: Input your age, resting heart rate, and max heart rate

steps.name: Estimate VO2 Max
steps.text: The tool calculates your VO2 Max estimate and level

useCases.title: Fitness Assessment
useCases.description: Know your cardiorespiratory fitness level

useCases.title: Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor fitness improvements with training

useCases.title: Sports Planning
useCases.description: Determine appropriate training zones

seoTips: Measure resting heart rate several days and take the average
VO2 Max improves with regular aerobic training
Professional athletes may reach 70-80 ml/kg/min
Values decrease with age by about 1% annually
commonMistakes: Measuring resting heart rate after activity or drinking coffee
Confusing estimated VO2 Max with lab-measured values
Expecting rapid improvements in VO2 Max
Comparing your values to people of different ages

faqs.question: What's a good VO2 Max value?
faqs.answer: For men: 35-40 average, 45-55 good, 60+ excellent. Women about 10% lower.

faqs.question: How do I improve VO2 Max?
faqs.answer: Through regular aerobic training, especially HIIT and long runs.

faqs.question: Is the estimate accurate?
faqs.answer: A good estimate, but lab testing is much more accurate.

heart-rate-zone-calculator.title: Heart Rate Zone Calculator - Target Training Zones
heart-rate-zone-calculator.description: Calculate your heart rate training zones for fat burning, cardio, and performance. Free online heart rate monitor tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Heart Rate Zone Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Max Heart Rate = 220 - Age, then zones are calculated as percentages
howItWorks.explanation: This tool divides your heart rate range into 5 training zones, each targeting different physiological adaptations. Training in the right zone ensures you achieve your goals efficiently.

steps.name: Enter Age
steps.text: Input your age to calculate max heart rate

steps.name: Enter Resting HR
steps.text: Input your resting heart rate for accuracy

steps.name: View Zones
steps.text: The tool calculates your five training zones

useCases.title: Fat Burning
useCases.description: Train in the fat burning zone (60-70% of max HR)

useCases.title: Endurance Improvement
useCases.description: Train in the aerobic zone to build endurance capacity

useCases.title: HIIT Training
useCases.description: Set intensity for high-intensity interval workouts

seoTips: Use a fitness watch to monitor heart rate during exercise
80% of your training should be in zones 1-3
The fat burning zone isn't the best for weight loss
Don't train in zone 5 for long periods
commonMistakes: Always training at high intensity thinking it's better
Ignoring training in lower zones
Using 220-age formula as absolute truth
Not using a device to measure heart rate

faqs.question: Which zone is best for fat burning?
faqs.answer: Zone 2-3, but high-intensity training burns more total calories.

faqs.question: Is the 220-age formula accurate?
faqs.answer: Estimated - actual max heart rate may vary by ±10-15 beats.

faqs.question: How often should I train in zone 5?
faqs.answer: Maximum 1-2 times weekly, with adequate rest afterward.

swimming-pace-calculator.title: Swimming Pace Calculator - Pace per 100m/100yd
swimming-pace-calculator.description: Calculate your swimming pace and speed accurately. Free online tool for swimmers to track and improve time performance.

howItWorks.title: How the Swimming Pace Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Pace per 100m = (Total Time in seconds ÷ Distance in meters) × 100
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your swimming pace per 100 meters, the standard unit in swimming. Knowing your pace helps you plan for races and improve your performance.

steps.name: Enter Distance
steps.text: Input the distance you swam in meters

steps.name: Enter Time
steps.text: Input total time (minutes and seconds)

steps.name: Calculate Pace
steps.text: The tool calculates your pace per 100 meters

useCases.title: Race Planning
useCases.description: Set target pace for swimming competitions

useCases.title: Interval Training
useCases.description: Set pace for interval swimming workouts

useCases.title: Comparing Strokes
useCases.description: Find which stroke is fastest for you

seoTips: 2:00/100m pace is good for recreational swimmers
Professional swimmers reach under 1:00/100m
Technique is more important than strength for improving pace
Train at different distances for comprehensive improvement
commonMistakes: Neglecting technique and focusing only on speed
Not using a waterproof watch for accurate timing
Comparing your pace to professional swimmers
Ignoring the importance of turns and starts

faqs.question: What's a good swimming pace?
faqs.answer: Recreational: 2:00-2:30/100m, Advanced: 1:30-2:00/100m, Elite: under 1:15/100m.

faqs.question: How do I improve my swim pace?
faqs.answer: By improving technique, breathing, stroke power, and interval training.

faqs.question: Does stroke type affect pace?
faqs.answer: Yes - butterfly is fastest, then freestyle, backstroke, then breaststroke.

cycling-power-calculator.title: Cycling Power Calculator - Wattage and Performance
cycling-power-calculator.description: Calculate the power output needed for cycling at specific speeds. Free online cycling wattage and performance tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Cycling Power Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Power = Air Resistance + Rolling Resistance + Climbing Power
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the power in watts needed to cycle at a specific speed. It considers rider and bike weight, wind speed, and road gradient.

steps.name: Enter Weights
steps.text: Input your weight and bike/equipment weight

steps.name: Enter Speed
steps.text: Input target speed and gradient

steps.name: Calculate Power
steps.text: The tool calculates required power in watts

useCases.title: Race Planning
useCases.description: Know the power needed to maintain a certain speed

useCases.title: Power Training
useCases.description: Set power goals for training

useCases.title: Equipment Selection
useCases.description: Understand the impact of weight on performance

seoTips: Power-to-weight ratio (W/kg) is more important than absolute power
3-4 W/kg is good for amateurs, 5-6 for professionals
Air resistance increases quadratically with speed
Aerodynamic positioning significantly reduces resistance
commonMistakes: Ignoring the effect of wind on actual performance
Focusing on absolute power rather than relative power
Not accounting for altitude and atmospheric pressure
Comparing your power without considering test conditions

faqs.question: What's good power for a cyclist?
faqs.answer: Amateurs: 2.5-3.5 W/kg, Advanced: 3.5-4.5, Professionals: 5+ W/kg.

faqs.question: How do I improve my power?
faqs.answer: Through interval training, climbing training, and increasing training volume.

faqs.question: Does bike weight matter?
faqs.answer: Yes for climbing, but aerodynamics matter more on flat terrain.

heart_rate_zones.title: Heart Rate Zones Calculator
heart_rate_zones.description: Determine ideal training zones based on your age and resting heart rate to ensure workout effectiveness.

inputs.resting_hr_tooltip: Measure your pulse immediately upon waking or after sitting quietly for 5 minutes

zones.maximum_desc: Intense effort for very short durations

heart_rate_zones.about_desc: Training in specific heart rate zones helps target specific goals such as fat burning or improving cardiorespiratory fitness.
heart_rate_zones.empty_state: Enter your age and resting pulse to determine your training zones
heart_rate_zones.footer_note: These zones are estimates. Consult a doctor before starting an intense training program.

howItWorks.title: How the Heart Rate Zones Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Max Heart Rate = 220 - Age, then zones are calculated as percentages of heart rate reserve
howItWorks.explanation: This tool divides your heart rate range into 5 distinct training zones, each targeting different physiological adaptations. Using the Karvonen formula with your resting heart rate provides more personalized and accurate zones than age-based formulas alone.

steps.name: Enter Age
steps.text: Input your age to calculate maximum heart rate

steps.name: Enter Resting HR
steps.text: Input your resting heart rate for more accurate zones

steps.name: View Training Zones
steps.text: Get your five personalized training zones with target heart rates

useCases.title: Fat Burning Optimization
useCases.description: Train in zones 2-3 (60-70% max HR) for optimal fat oxidation

useCases.title: Endurance Building
useCases.description: Build aerobic capacity with sustained training in the aerobic zone

useCases.title: HIIT Programming
useCases.description: Set accurate intensity targets for high-intensity interval training

seoTips: Use a heart rate monitor or fitness watch during workouts for real-time tracking
Spend 80% of training time in zones 1-3 for optimal endurance development
The fat burning zone is not necessarily the best for weight loss - higher zones burn more total calories
Avoid extended training in zone 5 without adequate recovery between sessions
commonMistakes: Always training at high intensity thinking more is better
Neglecting low-intensity training which builds aerobic base
Using the 220-age formula as absolute truth when individual variation exists
Not using a device to accurately monitor heart rate during training

faqs.question: Which zone is best for burning fat?
faqs.answer: Zone 2-3 maximizes fat oxidation, but higher intensity training burns more total calories and may be more effective for weight loss.

faqs.question: How accurate is the 220-age formula?
faqs.answer: It is an estimate with individual variation of plus or minus 10-15 beats. A max HR test provides more accuracy.

faqs.question: How often should I train in zone 5?
faqs.answer: Maximum 1-2 times weekly with adequate recovery. Excessive high-intensity training leads to overtraining.

vo2max.title: VO2 Max Calculator
vo2max.description: Estimate maximum oxygen consumption capacity, a key indicator of cardiorespiratory fitness.

inputs.max_hr_tooltip: If unknown, it will be calculated based on your age

vo2max.about_desc: It is the maximum rate of oxygen consumption during intense exercise, and is considered the best measure of cardiorespiratory endurance and general physical fitness.
vo2max.empty_state: Enter your data to estimate your VO2 Max level
vo2max.footer_note: This estimate is based on the relationship between resting pulse and maximum pulse.

howItWorks.title: How the VO2 Max Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: VO2 Max (ml/kg/min) = 15.3 × (Max Heart Rate / Resting Heart Rate)
howItWorks.explanation: VO2 Max represents the maximum amount of oxygen your body can utilize during intense exercise, measured in milliliters per kilogram of body weight per minute. It is considered the gold standard for measuring cardiorespiratory fitness and endurance capacity.

steps.name: Measure Resting HR
steps.text: Take your pulse first thing in the morning before getting out of bed

steps.name: Enter Data
steps.text: Input your age, resting heart rate, and maximum heart rate if known

steps.name: Get Estimate
steps.text: The calculator provides your estimated VO2 Max and fitness category

useCases.title: Fitness Level Assessment
useCases.description: Objectively measure your cardiorespiratory fitness compared to age and gender norms

useCases.title: Training Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor improvements in aerobic capacity over time with consistent training

useCases.title: Training Zone Planning
useCases.description: Use VO2 Max to determine appropriate training intensities and zones

seoTips: Measure resting heart rate over several days and use the average for better accuracy
VO2 Max improves with consistent aerobic training, especially interval training
Elite endurance athletes typically have VO2 Max values of 70-85 ml/kg/min
VO2 Max naturally decreases with age by approximately 1% per year after age 25
commonMistakes: Measuring resting heart rate after physical activity or caffeine consumption
Confusing estimated VO2 Max with laboratory-measured values
Expecting rapid improvements in VO2 Max (it takes months of consistent training)
Comparing your values to people of significantly different ages

faqs.question: What is a good VO2 Max value?
faqs.answer: For men: 35-40 is average, 45-55 is good, 60+ is excellent. Women are typically 10-15% lower in each category.

faqs.question: How can I improve my VO2 Max?
faqs.answer: Through consistent aerobic training, especially high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and long slow distance running.

faqs.question: How accurate is the estimate?
faqs.answer: This provides a reasonable estimate, but laboratory testing with gas analysis is much more accurate.

cycling_power.title: Cycling Power Calculator
cycling_power.description: Calculate the power output needed for cycling at specific speeds.
cycling_power.bike_weight_tooltip: Weight of your bike and gear
cycling_power.factors_desc: Calculations include gravity, air resistance, and rolling resistance.
cycling_power.empty_state: Enter parameters to calculate cycling power
cycling_power.footer_note: Simplified calculation. Actual power depends on wind, road surface, and position.

howItWorks.title: How the Cycling Power Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Power = Air Resistance Power + Rolling Resistance Power + Climbing Power
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines the power in watts needed to cycle at a specific speed considering multiple factors including rider and bike weight, speed, and road gradient. Air resistance increases exponentially with speed, making it the dominant factor at higher speeds.

steps.name: Enter Weights
steps.text: Input your body weight and bike/equipment weight

steps.name: Enter Speed
steps.text: Input your target cycling speed and road gradient

steps.name: Calculate Power
steps.text: Get the required power output and power-to-weight ratio

useCases.title: Race Planning
useCases.description: Determine the power needed to maintain target speeds during competitions

useCases.title: Training Targets
useCases.description: Set specific power goals for interval and threshold training

useCases.title: Equipment Decisions
useCases.description: Understand how bike weight and aerodynamics affect performance requirements

seoTips: Power-to-weight ratio (W/kg) is more important than absolute power for climbing
Amateur cyclists typically produce 2.5-3.5 W/kg, professionals 5-6 W/kg for sustained efforts
Air resistance increases with the square of speed, so doubling speed requires 8x the power
Aerodynamic position and equipment can reduce power requirements by 20-30%
commonMistakes: Ignoring wind conditions which significantly affect real-world power requirements
Focusing on absolute power rather than power-to-weight ratio
Not accounting for altitude and air density changes
Comparing power numbers without considering test conditions and equipment

faqs.question: What is a good power-to-weight ratio?
faqs.answer: Recreational: 2.5-3.5 W/kg, Amateur racer: 3.5-4.5 W/kg, Professional: 5-6+ W/kg for sustained efforts.

faqs.question: How can I improve my cycling power?
faqs.answer: Through interval training, hill repeats, structured training programs, and improving cycling efficiency.

faqs.question: Does bike weight really matter?
faqs.answer: Most for climbing. On flat terrain, aerodynamics matter more. A 1kg lighter bike saves about 3-5 watts on a 5% climb at 15 km/h.

race_predictor.title: Race Time Predictor
race_predictor.description: Predict your race finish time based on your current performance.
race_predictor.race_distance_tooltip: Distance of the race you completed
race_predictor.race_time_tooltip: Time taken to complete the race
race_predictor.target_distance_tooltip: Distance you want to predict time for
race_predictor.tip_train: Training for longer distances requires specific endurance work.
race_predictor.empty_state: Enter your race result to predict future performance
race_predictor.footer_note: Predictions use Riegel's formula. Actual performance depends on training.

howItWorks.title: How the Race Time Predictor Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool uses the scientifically-validated Riegel formula to predict your race time at a new distance based on a previous race performance. The formula accounts for the natural slowdown in pace that occurs as race distance increases.

steps.name: Enter Previous Race
steps.text: Input the distance and finish time of a recent race

steps.name: Select Target Distance
steps.text: Choose the distance you want to predict

steps.name: View Prediction
steps.text: Get your predicted finish time and target pace

useCases.title: Marathon Planning
useCases.description: Predict marathon time based on half marathon or 10K performance

useCases.title: Goal Setting
useCases.description: Set realistic and achievable goals for upcoming races

useCases.title: Race Readiness
useCases.description: Determine if you are ready to attempt a longer distance

seoTips: Use a recent race result from the past 2-3 months for accuracy
Predictions are more accurate between similar distances (10K to half marathon)
Distance-specific training significantly affects actual race performance
Weather, course terrain, and race-day conditions affect actual results
commonMistakes: Using training run times instead of actual race efforts
Predicting marathon time from only a 5K result (less accurate)
Ignoring the need for specific training for the target distance
Expecting prediction accuracy without proper training volume

faqs.question: How accurate are the predictions?
faqs.answer: Very accurate between similar distances. Predictions from half marathon to marathon are more reliable than from 5K to marathon.

faqs.question: Which race distance is best for prediction?
faqs.answer: Half marathon best predicts full marathon. 10K best predicts half marathon times.

faqs.question: Why might my actual race be different?
faqs.answer: Training specificity, nutrition, weather, course difficulty, and race-day factors all affect actual performance.

running_pace.title: Running Pace Calculator
running_pace.description: Calculate your running pace per kilometer or mile.
running_pace.tip_consistency: Consistent pace is key for long distance running
running_pace.tip_interval: Interval training can help improve your overall pace
running_pace.tip_rest: Rest days are important for speed improvement
running_pace.empty_state: Enter distance and time to calculate your pace
running_pace.footer_note: Pace calculation assumes a constant speed throughout the run.

howItWorks.title: How the Running Pace Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your running pace (time per kilometer or mile) based on distance covered and total time. Knowing your pace helps you plan training runs, set race goals, and track improvement over time.

steps.name: Enter Distance
steps.text: Input the distance you ran in kilometers

steps.name: Enter Time
steps.text: Input the total time (hours, minutes, seconds)

steps.name: Calculate Pace
steps.text: Get your pace per km/mile and average speed

useCases.title: Race Planning
useCases.description: Determine starting pace and target pace for upcoming races

useCases.title: Speed Training
useCases.description: Set specific pace targets for interval and tempo workouts

useCases.title: Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor pace improvements over time at consistent distances

seoTips: A 5:00 min/km pace is considered good for recreational runners
Start races slightly slower than your goal pace to avoid burnout
Train at different paces: easy, moderate, and fast for complete development
Monitor your easy run pace to avoid overtraining
commonMistakes: Starting too fast in races and fading in the later stages
Not accounting for elevation and weather when evaluating pace
Running every training session at race pace instead of varying intensity
Comparing your pace to more experienced runners with different training backgrounds

faqs.question: What is a good pace for beginners?
faqs.answer: 6:00-7:00 min/km is typical for beginners. Consistency matters more than speed when starting out.

faqs.question: How do I improve my pace?
faqs.answer: Through regular training, interval workouts, tempo runs, and long slow distance runs for aerobic base.

faqs.question: Should I always run at the same pace?
faqs.answer: No, variety is important. Follow the 80/20 rule: 80% easy running, 20% harder efforts.

swimming_pace.title: Swimming Pace Calculator
swimming_pace.description: Calculate your swimming pace and speed accurately.
swimming_pace.empty_state: Enter distance and time to calculate your swimming pace
swimming_pace.footer_note: Pace is calculated based on total time and distance.

howItWorks.title: How the Swimming Pace Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Pace per 100m = (Total Time in seconds / Distance in meters) × 100
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your swimming pace per 100 meters, the standard unit used in swimming. Knowing your pace helps plan race strategies, set training intervals, and track improvement across different strokes and distances.

steps.name: Enter Distance
steps.text: Input the distance you swam in meters

steps.name: Enter Time
steps.text: Input the total time (minutes and seconds)

steps.name: Calculate Pace
steps.text: Get your pace per 100 meters and average speed

useCases.title: Race Planning
useCases.description: Set target pace for swimming competitions and events

useCases.title: Interval Training
useCases.description: Set specific pace targets for swimming interval workouts

useCases.title: Stroke Comparison
useCases.description: Determine which swimming stroke is fastest for you

seoTips: A 2:00/100m pace is considered good for recreational swimmers
Elite swimmers can achieve under 1:00/100m in freestyle
Technique improvement often matters more than fitness for pace gains
Train at various distances to develop well-rounded swimming ability
commonMistakes: Neglecting swimming technique and focusing only on effort
Not using a waterproof watch or lap timer for accurate timing
Comparing your pace to competitive swimmers with years of training
Ignoring the importance of turns, push-offs, and starts in overall pace

faqs.question: What is a good swimming pace?
faqs.answer: Recreational: 2:00-2:30/100m, Intermediate: 1:30-2:00/100m, Competitive: under 1:20/100m for freestyle.

faqs.question: How do I improve my swimming pace?
faqs.answer: Through technique work, proper breathing, stroke efficiency, and structured interval training.

faqs.question: Does stroke type affect pace?
faqs.answer: Yes. For most swimmers: freestyle is fastest, followed by backstroke, then breaststroke, with butterfly being demanding but fast for short distances.
